conclusion: Solution outline for determining the mass ratio of A and C.
The two light, inextensible wires form two straight segments: Segment AB makes an angle θ = 30° with the horizontal rim, and Segment BC joins B to the rim on the right.
Both A and C hang vertically below the rim, and AB and BC are equal in length, each being a radius R of the hemisphere.
Forces on each ball are described.
Ball A experiences wire tension TAB upward along AB and its own weight mAg downward.
Ball B experiences two wire tensions TAB and TBC, its weight mBg downward, and zero normal force from the bowl wall.
Ball C experiences tension TBC upward along BC and its weight mCg downward.
Static equilibrium conditions for the balls are described.
For A and C, the forces must balance vertically.
For B, the vector sum of the two wire tensions must cancel its weight because there is no bowl reaction.
TAB and TBC are equal in magnitude because AB and BC subtend the same angle from B to the rim and the system is symmetric.
Key consequences of the equilibrium conditions are described.
At B, the two tensions T form an angle of 2θ = 60° with each other, and their vector sum equals 2T cos θ pointing straight upward.
Setting the upward resultant equal to the weight mBg gives 2T cos θ = mB g.
For A: vertical equilibrium gives T = mA g.
For C: T = mC g.
Relating the masses of the balls.
Equate T = mA g and T = mC g to get mA = mC.
Insert T = mA g into 2T cos θ = mB g to get mB = 2mA cos θ.
The problem asks for the ratio mA : mC, which is 1 : 1 from mA = mC.
The masses of spheres A and C must be equal; hence mA : mC = 1 : 1.
